channel.title: Welcome to my travel blog! on Blanka's Travel Blog
channel.description: Recent content in Welcome to my travel blog! on Blanka's Travel Blog

item.title: Aosta
item.description: Ahh, Aosta. Quelle magnifique! Can you imagine a small town in the valley surrounded by snow-peaked mountains, singing birds, alpine architecture and roman remains?

item.title: Cuneo & Saluzzo
item.description: La Granda. That’s the nickname of the Provincia di Cuneo. It is not because it sooo great - it has just the biggest territory.

item.title: Susa Valley
item.description: Ahh another mountain valley. I love them. They are perfect example of how these geographical barriers create special societies, which flourish not just culturally and socially, but also economically.

item.title: Bra and Alba
item.description: I know it is surprising, but Bra has nothing to with langeries, and Alba is not named after Jessica Alba.

item.title: Aosta valley
item.description: If you want to find functioning, pleasant villages in Italy, then the Aosta valley is the best place.

item.title: Sondrio & Domodossola
item.description: These two towns have quite similar base: the mountain valley culinary hotspots completely isolated from the the rest of the region.

item.title: Milano
item.description: Milano. If you tell anyone that you are in Milano, the general reaction is “ooo, how lucky you are what a beautiful city!

item.title: Como and Ticino
item.description: Chiasso The town has a really simple function: the border town between Lombardy and the Ticino canton.

item.title: Pavia
item.description: I finally found the Maastricht of Italy. The cute university town with a gezellig atmosphere, cute stoned streets, glorious history and fulfilling liveliness.

item.title: Mantova, Cremona
item.description: Renaissance, isolation and high life quality. What more do you need.

item.title: Omegna, Orta San Giulio
item.description: There are a few lakes in Italy hugged by the Alps which create a completely different vibe from the usual Mediterranean atmosphere.

item.title: Garda - The South
item.description: If you look at the Garda lake on the map,it’s pear shape is really apparent with the wide round south narrowing itself continuously into the mountain valley.

item.title: Ivrea
item.description: Ivrea is north of Torino, close to the border with Aosta but still part of Torino Metropolitan Area.

item.title: Le Cinque Terre
item.description: Liguria is just a jump away from both Piemonte and Lombardia.

item.title: Vercelli
item.description: We already payed a visit to Vercelli a few weeks ago.

item.title: Brescia
item.description: A week after our visit I learned from my classmate who is from Bergamo, that they hate Brescia.

item.title: Bergamo
item.description: Brescia and Bergamo have basically the same structure: the lower modern city and the upper historical part.

item.title: Asti
item.description: Just 30 minutes from Torino, the nest of the cultural elite can be found: Asti.

item.title: Garda - The West
item.description: It seemed like a good idea to book a weekend holidays at Lombardy til its such a good weather.

item.title: The Milano agglomeration
item.description: The unimaginable happened. We left our lovely Piemonte and crossed the magical line this ending up in Lombardy.

item.title: The Torino-Milano line
item.description: When arriving to the train station of Chivasso one would reconsider staying on the train and not getting out…

item.title: Genova
item.description: An italian trade city in the North of Italy, the competition to Venice!

item.title: Torino
item.description: I would have never imagined that one can find it pleasant to live in a big city.
